projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: ARTICLES TO BE INQVIRED of by the CHURCH-VVARDENS and Questmen of every Parish in the Lord Primates Visitation Metropoliticall.
DƲBLIN, Imprinted by the Society of Stationers, Printers to the Kings most excellent Majestie. 1640.

div.head:
The forme of the Oath to be taken by the Churchwardens and Questmen in every Parish in •••
diately before their presentmen ••
div.p: YOV, and euery of you shall sweare, that you shall due inquiry and true presentment make according to the Articles given you in charge, of all such crimes, faults, and defaults, as have bin committed in your Parish: And of all such persons, as are or have been vehemently suspected, or defamed to have committed any such crimes, faults, or defaults. You shall neither present any for hatred, malice, or any other sinister respect, nor spare any for feare, favour, or reward, but discharge your Consciences, as men fearing God, for the reformation of sinne and wickednesse, and the advancement of godlinesse and Vertue. So helpe you God.

div.head: I. Concerning Religion and Church-governement.
div.p:
INprimis. Doe you know any that doe refuse to receive or approve the Articles of Religion agréed upon in the Convocation holden at Londen, Anno Domini 1562. and recived here in the Convocation begun at Dublin,
•• o Domini 1634? or have you heard of any, who have traduced or ••• n against the same?

• . • lso doe you know or have you heard of any person vnthin your ••• ish, that doth acknowledge any manner of obedience or subiecti
••• be due to any forrain power in causes Ecclesiasticall? or that ••• er by word or writing hath maintained, that the Kings power ••• n this Realme of Ireland and all other his dominions and ••• ies is not the highest power under God, to whom all men by 〈◊〉 Lawes owe all loyaltie and obedience; and to no other power •• tentate upon earth?

• . Are there in your Parish any, who have traduced or spoken ••• nst the prescript forme of Divine Service contained in the Book Common-Prayer? or against the forme of consecrating and or
•• ng our Bishops and other Ministers? or have maintained that 〈◊〉 Churches established under this government be not true Chur
••• , or one refuse to ioyne with them in Christian profession?

4. Is the Lords-day, and other Holy-dayes appointed by the orders of this Church duely kept and observed? And are any other Holy-dayes observed, beside those which are appointed by the Booke of Common-Prayer?

div.head: II. Concerning Parish Churches and Ch • pp.
div.p: 5. Is your Parish Church or Chappell kept in due separation; the windowes well glazed, and the floozes kept p •• ne, no ••• n? and is your Church-yard well and sufficiently s •••• , 〈◊〉 intained with wals, rayles or pales, as hath beene heref ••• , 〈◊〉 accustomed?

6. Have you in your said Church or Chappell 〈◊〉 sit Seate for the Minister to reade Divine Service in, a decent Pulpit forth a comely Pulpit-Cloth and Cushion, a Font-stone with a cover, a fane Communion Table with a decent Carpet and a faire Linnen-cloth for the covering of the same, a Silver Cup with a cover, and a Stoop • or Flagon of Pewter (if not of purer mettall) for the celebration of the holy Communion?

7. Have you in your Church or Chappell two Bookes of Common-prayer (one for the Minister, and another for the Clerke) a B ••
ble of the last Translation, the Booke of Canons agra • upon in th • Convocation begun at Dublin Auno 1634. and a Table of the degrées of Marriage prohibited by the Lawes of God:

8. Have you a sure Coffer, with three locks and keyes (where of one remaineth with the Minister, the other two with the Churchwardens) and a Parchment-booke therein to be kept ••• th. eg •• string of every Christening, Wedding and Buriall within you Parish? And doth the Minister every Sabbathday, in the pr •
sence of the Church-wardens record in the said Book the wa ••• a surnames of all persons christened in the said Parish ••• the • wi •• the names of all persons married or b •• ied the wo • ke 〈◊〉
•••
ther
with the day and yeere of every such Marriage, Christning, and Buriall?

9. Have you a strong Chest, with a hole in the upper pa • t thereof (having thrée Reyes, to be kept as aforesaid) fastned in the most covement place, that the Parishioners way put thereinto their Almes for their poore neighbours?

10 Dee you know of any that hath shed bloud, or stricken, or quar
•• lled with any person in your Church or Church-yard?

11. Are all monuments of idolatry and superstition a bolished in your Church or Church-yard? Hath there been any pr • phane usage kept therein; either playes, feasts, banquet • , Church-Ales, or • nk •• gs, exposing any wares to sale, temporall Courts or Léet • , Lay
•• ies, Musters, Commissions (other than for causes Ecclesiasticall) playing at Ball, or any other unséemly actions or misbehavior?

div.head: III. Concerning Ministers.
div.p: 12. Is the Benefice within your Parish a Parsonage, Vicarage, or Prebend? who i • the Incumbent there? What tythes, Glebelands, or other rights or possessions are thereunto belonging? You are to bring a true note, or Terrier of the same into the Bishops Registry, there to be safely preserved?

13. Doth your Person or Vicar keepe his Manse-heuse, with all the buildings thereunto belonging in due reparation? Doth he reside, and keepe hospitality therein? If not, where doth he reside? and how, and by whom is the charge supplied?

14. Doth your Person, Vicar or Curate duely every Sunday, and Holy-day, and other times appointed doe his dnty, in reading distinctly Divine Service, and (as occasion requireth) administing the Sacraments; according to the forme prescribed in the Booke of Common-Prayer?

15. Doth your Minister begin and end Divine Service at due an • covenient houres? and doth he examine and instruct the youth of th • Parish every Sunday in the Catechisme set forth in the Booke of Common-Prayer, for halfe an houre before Evening Praye •

16. Doth he, for the fuller information of the people in the body of Christian Religion, divide the heads thereof into so many p ••• es there are Sundayes in the yeere? and in the hantling and ••••
ning thereof doth he use such moderation, that he doth not • unne in • o curious questions and unnecessary controversies, but shortly declare and confirme the doctrine proposed, and make application thereof to the behoofe of the hearers?

17. How many Benefices or Ecclesiasticall promo • ions hath your Person or Vicar; and how farre distant are they the one from the other? What Chappels hath he to his Cures belonging? by what names are they called? and how and by whom are they served?
18. Doth your Minister preach every Sunday in that Church where he is resident? and if not; doe you know that he hath any just impediment for the same?

19. Doth your Minister teach any vaine opinions, Heresies, or Popish errors, disagreeing from the Articles of Religion generally received in the Churches of England and Ireland? And doe you know, or have you heard any Preacher in the Pulpit particularly impugne or confute any doctrine delivered by any other Preacher in the same Church, or in any other neare adioyning; or otherwise make any publike opposition unto him? And have you acquainted the Bishop of the Diocese therewith?

20. Doth your Minister, or Proprietary (if the Benefice be impropriate) allow a competent maintenance to the Curate, who supplieth that charge? and what doth he allow him? Is the Curate licensed by the Bishop? And how many Churches or Chappels doth he serve in one day; and how farre distant are they one from the other?
21. Hath your Minister denyed or neglected to visit the sicke, or to Christen or bury any, when he hath been lawfully and conveniently required thereunto?
22. Hath he married any in any other place, save in the face of the Church, and at any other time, then betweene the houres of eight and twelve in the forenoone?

23. Doth your Minister give warning publikely in the Church at Morning Prayer the Sunday before the Communion is to be administred; to the end the Communicants may the better prepare themselves thereunto? or hath he admitted any knowne impenitent notorious offendors to the participation of the same? And doth he celebrate the holy Communion so often, that every Parishioner may receive thrice in the yeare at the least?

24. Hath he admitted any to be married, or to be Godfather or Godmother at the Baptisme of any Childe, or to receive the holy Communion; before they can say the Articles of the Beleefe, the Lords Prayer, and the Ten commandements in such a Language as they understand?

25. Doth your Minister conferre with Recusants within his Parish, to séeke to recall them from their ignorance and errours? Is he of a good and sober conversation? Or othewise doth he give himselfe to any base or servile labour, to playing at Dice, Cards or Tables, or any other game unbeséeming his function? Is he a common resorter to Tavernes or Alehouses, a great drinker, a Simoniacall person, a knowne Vsurer, a quartellous or contentious person, or otherwise defamed? Doth he also goe gravely and decently in his apparell; according as the Canons doe prescribe?

div.head: IIII. Concerning Cathedrall Churches, Deanes & Prebendaries.
div.p: 26. Whether the Cathedrall Church be in good repaire? what • ithes or rents doe belong unto it? who is the yearely receiver thereof; and how is the same bestowed?

27. Doth your Deane reside in the Cathedrall Church fourescore and ten dayes at the least in every yeare? Hath he any house, or ground to build an house upon, belonging to his Church? and doth he keep good hospitality, during the time of his residence?

28. Doe your Deane and Prebendaries preach in their owne persons (or by their substitutes, when they are lawfully absen • as often as by the ordinance and custome of their Church they are required? and in those other places and Churches also, whence they or the Cathedrall to which they belong doe receive any yearely • en • s or profits?

29. Do the Prebendaries, after the daies of their • es • ding in the Cathedrall (appointed by their locall statutes or custome • ) presently repaire to their Benefices; there to discharge their duties, according to the Law in that case provided?

div.head: V. Concerning the Parishioners.
div.p: 30. Are there any in your Parish, who are suspe •• ed to be of no Religion, méere Atheists, not adhering to any Church? or any that doe wilfully maintaine and defend any heresie, errour or opinion contrary to the Word of God? and have any gone about to seduce others from the truth of Religion taught & professed in our Church:

31. Are there in your Parish any, who séeme to professe the Faith and Religion of our Church, and formerly did frequent the Church and heare Divine service according to the Book of common-prayer, that doe now refuse or neglect diligently to frequent their Parish Church, and there reverently and devoutly to attend Gods. Service, and receive the holy Communion thrice in the yeare at the least, as it is required? Especially, you are to present the names of those, who have not communicated at Easter last?
32. Are there in your Parish any, that (in contempt of their owne Parish-church) doe resort any other Church or Chappell?

33. Are there in your Parish any, who upon the Sunday, or other allowed holy-dayes, doe use their manuall labour? or any that Buy • r Sell, or frequent Tavernes and Ale-houses in time of Di ••• e Service and preaching upon those dayes, and at those times?

34. Is there in your Parish any, that hath disturbed or hindred the Minister in the time of Divine Service or Sermon, or other wise effended the people by walking, talking, laughing, or any other noise or clamour? Or that bring to the Church with them Hawkes with •• ls, or ill nurtured children which cannot be kept quiet in their Seats without running up and downe?
35. Have there any Bastards or base begotten children bene borne, •• are nursed within your Parish since the last Visitation? Present the names of the reputed Parents?
36. Are there any in your Parish that live together as Man and Wife, and yet are vehemently suspected not so be married, or to •• ve another Husband or Wife?

37. Are there any in your Parish, who being under the governement of their Parents or others, have made privie Contracts of Ma
•• mony; not calling thereunto two or moe witnesses, nor having the consent of their Parents, or such others under whose governement they are?

39. What married persons in your Parish have been divorced, and since married with others, for these thrée yéeres last past? By whose sentence were they divorced; and by whose licence, and by whom were they so married? Declare your knowledge in the premises, and what you have credibly heard?

40. Are there any in your Parish which are excommunicated? and how long have they stood so? Are there any who are reputed, or knowne to be common Drunkards, Swearers, Blasphemers, Incestuous persons, Adulterers, Fornicators, Bawdes, Per ••• ed persons, Extortioners, or Oppressors, Common scolds, Brawlers, Slanderers, Make=bates, Sowers of discord betwéene party and parlie, especially betwéene Man and Wife? Or that have used Cha ••• es, Spels, Sorcery or Witchcraft, or are guilty of any other notorious offence belonging to Ecclesiasticall cognisance, or are suspected 〈◊〉 defamed to be guilty of the same?
41. Hath any person within your Parish contemner 〈…〉 by word or déed, any Minister of the Church?

42. Doe any in your Parish deny or detaine their pay ••••
•••• ly rated towards the reparation and furnishing of the Ch •••••
〈…〉 other necessary pious use?
43. What persons in your Parish, having Goode or Chattels, have died since the last Visitation?
44. Have any within your Parish medled with the Goods or Chattels of parties deceased, without licence first had by le • t • s of administration or otherwise from the Ordinary?

45. Doe you know in your Parish any Executors of the goods of persons deceased, that have detained any Orphans goods, or Legacies bequeathed or appointed for the repairing of Churches or Highwayes, finding of poore Schollers, marrying of poore M •• dens, or such other charitable Déeds; and not employed the said Goods or Legacies according to their authority given and charge e •• oyned.

div.head: V, Concerning Parish-Clearks, Church-wardens, and Schoole-masters.
div.p:
16. Is your Parish-Clearke of competent age and ek •• l for the
••• cuting of his office? Is he resident, and doth he diligently per
•• me his duty in his owne person? • s he conformable to the Orders 〈◊〉 the Church, and of honest life and sober conversation?

47. Were your Church-wardens and Side men duely chosen at the time, and after the manner appointed; namely upon Monday 〈◊〉 Tuesday in Easter weeke, by the ioynt consent of the Minister and Parishioners? or otherwise, the one by the Minister, and the •• her by the Parishioners? And were they sworne the next Censi
•• y day after their election before the Bishop or his Chancell? Or 〈◊〉 there any so chosen, who have refused to undertake that Office?

48. Have the former Church-wardens, at the going forth out of 〈◊〉 Office, given up a true account of what moneyes they have re
•• ved and disbursed? Have they brought in a Register of all Chri
••• ings, Marriages and Burialls, within the yeare of their office; ••• t the same may faithfully be preserved in the Bishops Regestry?

49. Doe the Church-wardens, with the advice and direction of the •••• ster, provide against every Communion a sufficient quantitie 〈◊〉 fi • e white Bread, and of good and wholesome Wine, for the number of the Communicants that shall from time to time receive? And 〈◊〉 they performe all other duties aswell in the Church as without, ••• uired of them by the Canons and Constitutions of this Church?
50. What Schoole-masters or Vshers have you in your Parish, • ho teach Schoole either publikely or privately without Licence; 〈◊〉 by whom are they harboured?

div.head: VII. Concerning Ecclesiasticall Courts and their Officers.
div.p:
51. Is your Chancellour, Commissary, Officiall, or Surr • gate ••• sonably well practised in the course of the Ecclesiasticall and C •
• ll Lawes; and such an one as is twenty si • yeares old at least, and ••• ching whose life and conversation no evill report hath gone? And
doth he give any yearely Rent, summe or summes of money, or other consideration for his exercising of the Ecclesiasticall Im •• e ••••• to any person or persons whats • ever?

52. Do such as exercise Ecclesiasticall Iurisdiction deliver to the Churchwardens of every Parish such Bookes of Articles as any of them shall require for the yeare following; to ground th •• presentiments upon, at such times as they are to exhibite them?

53. Doth any Ecclesiasticall Iudge suffer any generall Preces 〈◊〉
Quorum nomina to be sent out of his Count; wherein the •••• es o • all such as are thereby to be cited are not first entred by the hand o • the Register or his deputy? and are such Processes also names first subscribed by the Iudge or his deputy, & his Seale affixed thereunto?

54. Do you know any person appearing upon a ••• ation, that hat • not bene dismissed with his costs; if the next Court day a •••• the •• have not bene Articles or a Libell put in against him? And der 〈◊〉 know of any, that hath bene excommunicated upon the first citation?

55. Hath any person executing Ecclesiasticall Iurisdiction expedited any iudiciall Act, without the Register of the Court or his law full deputy, or (in their absence) in the presence of such perious as 〈◊〉 Law are thereunto allowed?
56. Do you know or have heard of any exercising Ecclesiasticall Iutisdiction, that useth more then one Seale, for the sealing of all matters incident to his Office?

57. Do those that exercise Ecclesiasticall Iurisdiction appoint suc • meete places for the kéeping of their Courts (by the assignement o • approbation of the Bishop of the Diocese) as shall be convement for entertainment of those who are to make their appearance there, and most indifferent for their travell? And doe they keepe and end their Courts in such convenient time, as every man may returne homewards, in as due season as may be?

58. Hath any Iudge Ecclesiasticall, or his Surrogate yeèlded 〈◊〉
〈◊〉 probation of any Testament, or to the granting of an Admini
•• tion of the good • s of any person dying intestate; before the Execu
•••• or suiter for such administration hath first in his owne person (and 〈◊〉 by Proctor) taken the Oath accustomed in these cases?

59. Do you know or have you heard, that any Register or his de
••• y hath received any certificate without the consent of the Iudge ••• e Court? or willingly omitted to cause any persons (cited to •••• are upon any Court day) to be called? or unduely deferred the •••• mation of witnesses to bee examined by a day assigned by the •• age? or hath falsified any acts or records; or hath done any other ••• ng whereby the Iudge of the Court or his proceeding may be de
••• ed?

60. Do you know or have you heard, that any Proctor doth retaine •••• es without lawfull assignement of the parties? or doth refuse to 〈◊〉 the Oath De Calumnia, wheresoever in the suit the same shall ••• dred before sentence?

61. Hath any Apparitor cited any within your Parish to appeare 〈◊〉 any Ecclesiasticall Court without lawfull processe? Or hath mole
••• any without iust cause and ground; upon bare suspition, without ••• entment made or publique same preceding? Hath he exacted more ••• es then his due? Or hath he taken Bribes to defeat the Court, and ••• lease any delinquents?

62. Hath any Officer or Substitute in any Ecclesiasticall Court •• dulently delayed or betrayed any cause brought before them? or •••• ed more Fées then were due? or have taken any Bribes or Mo
••• under-hand, to winke at, and to suffer offences to escape unpuni
• ed?

63. Is there in your Parish any other matter or cause of the Cognizance of the Church, above not expressed, worthy presentment in your iugdement? If any such matter or cause there be; you are charged likewise to present the same, as you are the rest, by vertue of your Oath?
